page.title: Pronouns - Reflexives
page.introduction: Reflexives are another type of pronouns that most languages have. They occur only in the same case as direct objects and normally must agree with the subject in person, gender, and number features. Examples in English are: herself, himself, themselves, myself. Some languages have a completely separate set of pronoun forms for reflexives, others use a phrase which consists of a noun (usually meaning ‘self’) that is possessed by the pronoun that refers back to the subject, some languages have a verbal affix to indicate reflexive action, and some languages do not distinguish reflexive constructions at all.

radioGroup.prompt: Does your language have (any type of) reflexives?
radioGroup.radio: Yes, a pronoun or possessed noun fills the object position
Yes, a verbal affix indicates reflexive action

form.prompt: Key your reflexive examples here, with each on a separate line and followed by a period, beginning with first person, then second person, then third person:

radioGroup.prompt: Are the reflexive pronouns built by adding an affix to other pronouns, as in English?
radioGroup.radio: Yes, one or more affixes are chosen among to make another pronoun reflexive
No, they are distinct, stand alone words
No, a phrase consisting of a certain noun with a pronoun as the possessor is used
